elements.content: Reaction of Ni­(NCS)2 with 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine in acetonitrile leads to the formation of a new coordination polymer with the composition Ni­(NCS)2(4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine)2·MeCN (1-MeCN). In the crystal structure the Ni­(II) cations are linked by the anionic ligands into chains that are further connected into layers by intermolecular N–H···O hydrogen bonding. These layers are stacked and channels are formed, in which acetonitrile molecules are located. Solvent removal leads to the ansolvate 1, which shows microporosity as proven by sorption measurements. Single crystal X-ray investigations reveal that the solvent removal leads to a change in symmetry from primitive to C-centered, which is reversible and which proceeds via a topotactic reaction leaving the network intact. The magnetic properties of 1-MeCN and 1 are governed by the ferromagnetic exchange between spins of Ni­(II) forming chains. The susceptibility and specific heat for such a quantum Heisenberg chain of S = 1 spins with zero-field splitting are calculated using the DMRG method and compared with the experimental results.
elements.clean_text: Reaction of Ni(NCS)2 with 4-(Boc-amino)pyridine in acetonitrile leads to the formation of a new coordination polymer with the composition Ni(NCS)2(4-(Boc-amino)pyridine)2⋅MeCN (1-MeCN). In the crystal structure the Ni(II) cations are linked by the anionic ligands into chains that are further connected into layers by intermolecular N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding. These layers are stacked and channels are formed, in which acetonitrile molecules are located. Solvent removal leads to the ansolvate 1, which shows microporosity as proven by sorption measurements. Single crystal X-ray investigations reveal that the solvent removal leads to a change in symmetry from primitive to C-centered, which is reversible and which proceeds via a topotactic reaction leaving the network intact. The magnetic properties of 1-MeCN and 1 are governed by the ferromagnetic exchange between spins of Ni(II) forming chains. The susceptibility and specific heat for such a quantum Heisenberg chain of S = 1 spins with zero-field splitting are calculated using the DMRG method and compared with the experimental results.

elements.content: A new Ni­(NCS)2 coordination polymer was prepared that contains channels in which acetonitrile is embedded that can reversibly be removed leading to microporosity. Single crystal investigations prove that this reaction is topotactic, which is accompanied by a change of the lattice type from P to C. Magnetic and specific heat measurements reveal significant differences between the solvate and the ansolvate and their temperature dependence was modeled using DMRG calculations.
elements.clean_text: A new Ni(NCS)2 coordination polymer was prepared that contains channels in which acetonitrile is embedded that can reversibly be removed leading to microporosity. Single crystal investigations prove that this reaction is topotactic, which is accompanied by a change of the lattice type from P to C. Magnetic and specific heat measurements reveal significant differences between the solvate and the ansolvate and their temperature dependence was modeled using DMRG calculations.

elements.content: The synthesis and characterization of new coordination compounds with different physical properties, e.g., luminescence, conductivity, chirality, porosity, or magnetism, is still a major field in coordination chemistry. In this context, multifunctional compounds in which a property can be switched or tuned as a function of external parameters or that show reversible solvent or gas removal are of special interest. Within this field metal organic frameworks might be the most intensely investigated materials but there is an increasing number of so-called porous coordination polymers, in which, e.g., solvents can reversible be incorporated or removed. In several cases the solvate and the ansolvate have completely different structures and the framework collapses during solvent removal, but there are also examples where the solvate and the ansolvate are strongly structurally related and the solvent removal might proceed via a topotactic reaction. However, to prove such assumptions, SC-XRD measurements must be performed.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The synthesis and characterization of new coordination compounds with different physical properties, e.g., luminescence, conductivity, chirality, porosity, or magnetism, is still a major field in coordination chemistry. In this context, multifunctional compounds in which a property can be switched or tuned as a function of external parameters or that show reversible solvent or gas removal are of special interest. Within this field metal organic frameworks might be the most intensely investigated materials but there is an increasing number of so-called porous coordination polymers, in which, e.g., solvents can reversible be incorporated or removed. In several cases the solvate and the ansolvate have completely different structures and the framework collapses during solvent removal, but there are also examples where the solvate and the ansolvate are strongly structurally related and the solvent removal might proceed via a topotactic reaction. However, to prove such assumptions, SC-XRD measurements must be performed.

elements.content: In our investigations we are especially interested in the synthesis and magnetic properties of transition metal thiocyanate coordination polymers with additional N-donor coligands, in which the metal cations are linked by the anionic ligands into coordination polymers. In most cases 1D thiocyanate networks are obtained, in which the cations are linked into chains by pairs of anionic ligands, but layered thiocyanate networks are also observed. To increase the interchain or interlayer distance we became interested in the relatively large ligand 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine (4-(tert-butoxycarbonylamino)­pyridine or 2-methyl-2-propanyl 4-pyridinylcarbamate) (1), that can coordinate with the pyridine N atom to the metal centers but might also link the thiocyanate substructures by intermolecular N–H···O hydrogen bonding into networks of higher dimensionality. In the course of our investigations we obtained a new Ni­(II) coordination polymer, in which Ni­(NCS)2 chains are linked by the coligand into layers, which are stacked, forming channels in which acetonitrile molecules are located. For this compound, the solvent removal was investigated for its reversibility, if it proceeds via a topotactic reaction and how this will influence the magnetic properties. The latter were analyzed using a model chain of S = 1 spins with Heisenberg exchange and zero-field splitting anisotropy. The theoretical treatment of such a quantum system is a demanding task due to lack of solvable models that could be directly applied in this case. Several approaches were tried in the present work and finally only the recently developed method based on the density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) led to satisfactory results. We numerically calculated the magnetic susceptibility and the specific heat and compared those results with the experiment.

elements.content: NiSO4·6H2O was obtained from Merck, Ba­(NCS)2·3H2O was obtained from Alfa Aesar and 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. All solvents and reactants were used without further purification. Ni­(NCS)2 was prepared by the reaction of equimolar amounts of NiSO4·6H2O and Ba­(NCS)2·3H2O in water. The resulting white precipitate of BaSO4 was filtered off and the filtrate was dried. The phase purity of all compounds was verified by X-ray powder diffraction and elemental analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General

NiSO4⋅6H2O was obtained from Merck, Ba(NCS)2⋅3H2O was obtained from Alfa Aesar and 4-(Boc-amino)pyridine was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. All solvents and reactants were used without further purification. Ni(NCS)2 was prepared by the reaction of equimolar amounts of NiSO4⋅6H2O and Ba(NCS)2⋅3H2O in water. The resulting white precipitate of BaSO4 was filtered off and the filtrate was dried. The phase purity of all compounds was verified by X-ray powder diffraction and elemental analysis.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals for X-ray structure determination were obtained by the reaction of Ni­(NCS)2 (8.9 mg, 0.05 mmol) with 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine (9.7 mg, 0.05 mmol) in 1.5 mL of acetonitrile in a closed test tube at room temperature for several weeks. A crystalline powder on a larger scale was obtained by the reaction of Ni­(NCS)2 (52.5 mg, 0.30 mmol) with 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine (116.5 mg, 0.60 mmol) in 2.5 mL acetonitrile. The residue formed was filtered off, washed with acetonitrile, and dried in air. Yield: 87.7%. Elemental analysis for C24H31N7NiO4S2 (604.38 g/mol): C 47.70, H 5.17, N 16.22, S 9.71. Found: C 47.64, H 5.21, N 16.09, S 10.65. IR (ATR): νmax (cm–1) = 3313 (m), 3177 (w), 2990 (w), 2130 (m), 2111 (s), 1704 (s), 1610 (m), 1590 (s), 1517 (s), 1502 (m), 1422 (m), 1395 (m), 1369 (m), 1332 (m), 1277 (s), 1256 (s), 1238 (m), 1209 (s), 1150 (s), 1107 (m), 1058 (m), 1016 (s), 954 (w), 909 (w), 831 (s), 780 (m), 751 (m), 706 (m), 661 (m), 608 (m), 539 (s), 470 (m) (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

CHNS analysis was performed using an EURO EA elemental analyzer, fabricated by EURO VECTOR Instruments.

X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRPD)

The measurements were performed with Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.540598 Å) using a Stoe Transmission Powder Diffraction System (STADI P) that is equipped with a MYTHEN 1K detector and a Johansson-type Ge(111) monochromator and a PANalytical X’Pert Pro MPD Reflection Powder Diffraction System equipped with an Anton Paar HTK 1200N high temperature chamber and a PIXcel semiconductor detector.

Elemental Analysis

CHNS analysis was performed using an EURO EA elemental analyzer, fabricated by EURO VECTOR Instruments.

X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRPD)

The measurements were performed with Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.540598 Å) using a Stoe Transmission Powder Diffraction System (STADI P) that is equipped with a MYTHEN 1K detector and a Johansson-type Ge(111) monochromator and a PANalytical X'Pert Pro MPD Reflection Powder Diffraction System equipped with an Anton Paar HTK 1200N high temperature chamber and a PIXcel semiconductor detector.

elements.content: DTA-TG measurements were performed in a dynamic nitrogen atmosphere (purity: 5.0) in Al2O3 crucibles using a STA-409CD thermobalance from Netzsch. The instrument was calibrated using standard reference materials. All measurements were performed with a flow rate of 75 mL·min–1 and were corrected for buoyancy. The MS investigations were performed using a Quadrupol mass spectrometer from Balzers.
elements.clean_text:
Differential Thermal Analysis and Thermogravimetry (DTA-TG)

DTA-TG measurements were performed in a dynamic nitrogen atmosphere (purity: 5.0) in Al2O3 crucibles using a STA-409CD thermobalance from Netzsch. The instrument was calibrated using standard reference materials. All measurements were performed with a flow rate of 75 mL⋅min-1 and were corrected for buoyancy. The MS investigations were performed using a Quadrupol mass spectrometer from Balzers.

elements.content: Magnetic measurements were performed for powder samples of 1-MeCN and 1 using a MPMS squid magnetometer. This was done a week after the synthesis and XRPD tests, so to ensure the correct solvent content the powder of 1-MeCN was kept overnight at room temperature in an atmosphere saturated with MeCN and was cooled to 200 K before pumping the sample space for magnetic measurements. The sample of 1 was annealed in air at 90 °C for 1 h. The diamagnetic contributions of the sample holder and the core diamagnetism were subtracted, using measured and calculated values, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Measurements

Magnetic measurements were performed for powder samples of 1-MeCN and 1 using a MPMS squid magnetometer. This was done a week after the synthesis and XRPD tests, so to ensure the correct solvent content the powder of 1-MeCN was kept overnight at room temperature in an atmosphere saturated with MeCN and was cooled to 200 K before pumping the sample space for magnetic measurements. The sample of 1 was annealed in air at 90 °C for 1 h. The diamagnetic contributions of the sample holder and the core diamagnetism were subtracted, using measured and calculated values, respectively.

elements.content: Specific heat was measured by the relaxation technique using a Quantum Design PPMS with He3 cooling. Powders were pressed into thin pellets. Apiezon N grease was used to ensure thermal contact of the samples with the microcalorimeter. The heat capacity of the grease was measured before each run and subtracted from the measured data.
elements.clean_text:
Specific Heat Measurements

Specific heat was measured by the relaxation technique using a Quantum Design PPMS with He3 cooling. Powders were pressed into thin pellets. Apiezon N grease was used to ensure thermal contact of the samples with the microcalorimeter. The heat capacity of the grease was measured before each run and subtracted from the measured data.

elements.content: The specific surface area was determined with N2 sorption measurements using a Belsorp Max from BEL Japan INC. Before the measurement the sample was outgassed for 1 h at 90 °C in vacuum and for additional 16 h at RT in vacuum.
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Measurements

The specific surface area was determined with N2 sorption measurements using a Belsorp Max from BEL Japan INC. Before the measurement the sample was outgassed for 1 h at 90 °C in vacuum and for additional 16 h at RT in vacuum.

elements.content:
The IR spectra were measured using an ATI Mattson Genesis Series FTIR Spectrometer, control software: WINFIRST, from ATI Mattson.

X-ray Single Crystal Structure Analyses

Data collections were performed with an imaging plate diffraction system IPDS-2 from STOE & CIE using Mo Kα radiation. A numerical absorption correction was applied using programs X-RED and X-SHAPE of the program package X-Area. The crystal structure solution was performed with SHELXT and structure refinement was performed against F 2 using SHELXL-2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. All hydrogen atoms were positioned with idealized geometries (methyl H atoms of the acetonitrile molecules allowed to rotate but not to tip) and were refined isotropically with U iso(H) = −1.2 U eq(C) (1.5 for methyl H atoms) using a riding model.
elements.clean_text:
IR Spectroscopy

The IR spectra were measured using an ATI Mattson Genesis Series FTIR Spectrometer, control software: WINFIRST, from ATI Mattson.

X-ray Single Crystal Structure Analyses

Data collections were performed with an imaging plate diffraction system IPDS-2 from STOE & CIE using Mo Kα radiation. A numerical absorption correction was applied using programs X-RED and X-SHAPE of the program package X-Area. The crystal structure solution was performed with SHELXT and structure refinement was performed against F 2 using SHELXL-2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. All hydrogen atoms were positioned with idealized geometries (methyl H atoms of the acetonitrile molecules allowed to rotate but not to tip) and were refined isotropically with U iso(H) = -1.2 U eq(C) (1.5 for methyl H atoms) using a riding model.

elements.content: The experiments on solvent removal were performed using three different crystals, and therefore, significant differences in the quality of the data sets and the refinements are observed. 1-MeCN crystallizes as plates with the platelet plane corresponding to the (001) crystal face, and thus, the channels are directed perpendicular to this plane. Therefore, the crystals were mounted on a glass fiber with glue in a way that the pores are not blocked. Afterward each of these crystals was treated in vacuum at 60 °C for some time, investigated by single crystal X-ray diffraction, and the acetonitrile content was determined by refining the site occupation factor of the solvent atoms and/or by calculating the number of electrons within the voids using squeeze in Platon. To prove if the acetonitrile can be reintercalated, crystals from which the solvent was removed were stored in an acetonitrile atmosphere for about 1 day, but in this case, the glue used to fix the crystal loses its adhesive power. Therefore, the solvent was removed completely from other crystals; afterward some representative samples were checked using thermogravimetry. These crystals were then stored in a saturated acetonitrile atmosphere and one of them was investigated by single crystal structure determination. Selected crystal data and results of the structure refinements are given in Table S1.

Therefore, the crystals were mounted on a glass fiber with glue in a way that the pores are not blocked. Afterward each of these crystals was treated in vacuum at 60 °C for some time, investigated by single crystal X-ray diffraction, and the acetonitrile content was determined by refining the site occupation factor of the solvent atoms and/or by calculating the number of electrons within the voids using squeeze in Platon. To prove if the acetonitrile can be reintercalated, crystals from which the solvent was removed were stored in an acetonitrile atmosphere for about 1 day, but in this case, the glue used to fix the crystal loses its adhesive power. Therefore, the solvent was removed completely from other crystals; afterward some representative samples were checked using thermogravimetry. These crystals were then stored in a saturated acetonitrile atmosphere and one of them was investigated by single crystal structure determination. Selected crystal data and results of the structure refinements are given in Table S1.

elements.content: Reaction of Ni­(NCS)2 with 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine in acetonitrile leads to the formation of a crystalline phase, for which the asymmetric CN stretching vibration is observed at 2111 and 2130 cm–1 indicating that μ-1,3-bridging anionic ligands are present (Figure S1 in the SI). Thermogravimetric measurements indicate that it contains acetonitrile as solvate molecule, and elemental analysis reveal a composition of Ni­(NCS)2(4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine)2·MeCN (1-MeCN) (Figure S2). Single crystals of this compound were obtained from acetonitrile solution and were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. If the experimental XRPD pattern of 1-MeCN is compared with that calculated, it is proven that it is obtained as a pure phase (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthetic and Structural Investigations

Reaction of Ni(NCS)2 with 4-(Boc-amino)pyridine in acetonitrile leads to the formation of a crystalline phase, for which the asymmetric CN stretching vibration is observed at 2111 and 2130 cm-1 indicating that μ-1,3-bridging anionic ligands are present (Figure S1 in the SI). Thermogravimetric measurements indicate that it contains acetonitrile as solvate molecule, and elemental analysis reveal a composition of Ni(NCS)2(4-(Boc-amino)pyridine)2⋅MeCN (1-MeCN) (Figure S2). Single crystals of this compound were obtained from acetonitrile solution and were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction. If the experimental XRPD pattern of 1-MeCN is compared with that calculated, it is proven that it is obtained as a pure phase (Figure S3).

elements.content: 1-MeCN crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with four formula units in the unit cell. The asymmetric unit consists of one Ni cation, two thiocyanato anions, two 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine ligands, and one acetonitrile molecule in general positions. In the crystal structure the metal centers are octahedrally coordinated by two N and two S bonded thiocyanato anions as well as two 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine ligands that are coordinated via the pyridine N atom to the metal centers ( and Figure S4). The Ni–N distances are between 2.0324(18) and 2.1013(17) Å and the Ni–S distances range from 2.5477(6) to 2.5650(6) Å (Table S2). The angles around the Ni centers range from 85.31(5)° to 92.69(5)° and from 176.63(5)° to 177.35(5)°, which shows that the octahedra are slightly distorted (Table S2).

elements.content: The Ni­(II) cations are linked by pairs of thiocyanato anions into chains that elongate in the direction of the crystallographic c-axis. Along the chain each N and each S atom of the thiocyanato anions are strictly cis-coordinating, whereas the N atoms of the neutral ligand are trans-coordinating, leading to a zigzag-like arrangement ( top). These chains are further linked by intermolecular N–H···O hydrogen bonding between the N–H H atom of one 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine ligand of one chain and the carbonyl O atom of a ligand of a neighboring chain into layers, that are parallel to the b-c-plane ( top and ). Bond lengths and angles indicate that this is a strong interaction (). By this arrangement relatively rigid channels are formed within these layers that proceed along the c-axis parallel to the Ni­(NCS)2 chains ( top). In these channels acetonitrile solvent molecules are embedded that are linked into zigzag chains by intermolecular C–H···N hydrogen bonding between one methyl H atom of one acetonitrile molecule and the N atom of a neighboring molecule ( bottom and ).

The layers are stacked onto each other along the a-axis in a way that the coligands of one layer fit perfectly into the aperture formed by the coligands of neighboring layers (). Between the layers, several relatively short intermolecular O···H distances are observed, indicating weak C–H···O interactions (). In this way a relatively rigid 3-D framework with channels is formed, which might allow that the solvent can be removed without collapsing the structure, presumably in a topotactic reaction ().

elements.content: To investigate which changes might occur on solvent removal, the powder pattern of 1-MeCN was recalculated without acetonitrile, which indicates that the intensity of the (200) and (400) reflection located at 2θ = 6.67° and 13.35° should change dramatically and, thus, might be used to follow this reaction (Figure S5). Moreover, careful inspection of the reflection intensities measured for 1-MeCN shows that all reflections hkl with h + k = 2n + 1 are very weak, which indicates that a pseudo C-centering is present, which is also detected by the addsym option in Platon (Fit: 94%) (Table S3). Interestingly, if the acetonitrile molecule is removed from the structure model and the symmetry is checked with Platon, space group C2/c is suggested. Obviously, the acetonitrile molecules embedded in the channels lead to very weak “superstructure” reflections which are responsible for a primitive crystal system to be observed. Thus, if the solvent can be removed a change of symmetry from primitive to C-centered might occur at some definite composition.
elements.clean_text: To investigate which changes might occur on solvent removal, the powder pattern of 1-MeCN was recalculated without acetonitrile, which indicates that the intensity of the (200) and (400) reflection located at 2θ = 6.67° and 13.35° should change dramatically and, thus, might be used to follow this reaction (Figure S5). Moreover, careful inspection of the reflection intensities measured for 1-MeCN shows that all reflections hkl with h + k = 2n + 1 are very weak, which indicates that a pseudo C-centering is present, which is also detected by the addsym option in Platon (Fit: 94%) (Table S3). Interestingly, if the acetonitrile molecule is removed from the structure model and the symmetry is checked with Platon, space group C2/c is suggested. Obviously, the acetonitrile molecules embedded in the channels lead to very weak "superstructure" reflections which are responsible for a primitive crystal system to be observed. Thus, if the solvent can be removed a change of symmetry from primitive to C-centered might occur at some definite composition.

elements.content: Measurements using simultaneously differential thermoanalysis and thermogravimetry (DTA-TG) on 1-MeCN at 1 °C/min until 500 °C shows four mass steps in the TG curve that are accompanied by endothermic events in the DTA curve (Figure S6). The experimental mass loss of the first step of 6.9% is in very good agreement with that calculated for the removal of the solvent molecules (Δm calc. = 6.8%). The second mass step of 32.7% points to the removal of half of the 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine ligands (Δm calc. = 32.1%), that might lead to a compound of composition Ni­(NCS)2(4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine) (1). A closer look at the DTA and the DTG curve shows a double signal for the next step, which indicates that the last ligand is removed in discrete steps. If the ansolvate (1) obtained by thermogravimetric measurements after the first mass loss is investigated by XRPD only minor changes are observed but the intensity of the prominent (200) and (400) reflections decreased as already indicated by the XRPD pattern of 1-MeCN calculated with and without acetonitrile (Figure S7). The formation of 1 is also indicated by IR spectroscopic measurements, because the low intensity band at 2251 cm–1 that originates from the asymmetric CN stretching vibration of the acetonitrile molecules is absent (Figure S8).

Investigations on the Solvent Removal Using Crystalline Powders

Measurements using simultaneously differential thermoanalysis and thermogravimetry (DTA-TG) on 1-MeCN at 1 °C/min until 500 °C shows four mass steps in the TG curve that are accompanied by endothermic events in the DTA curve (Figure S6). The experimental mass loss of the first step of 6.9% is in very good agreement with that calculated for the removal of the solvent molecules (Δm calc. = 6.8%). The second mass step of 32.7% points to the removal of half of the 4-(Boc-amino)pyridine ligands (Δm calc. = 32.1%), that might lead to a compound of composition Ni(NCS)2(4-(Boc-amino)pyridine) (1). A closer look at the DTA and the DTG curve shows a double signal for the next step, which indicates that the last ligand is removed in discrete steps. If the ansolvate (1) obtained by thermogravimetric measurements after the first mass loss is investigated by XRPD only minor changes are observed but the intensity of the prominent (200) and (400) reflections decreased as already indicated by the XRPD pattern of 1-MeCN calculated with and without acetonitrile (Figure S7). The formation of 1 is also indicated by IR spectroscopic measurements, because the low intensity band at 2251 cm-1 that originates from the asymmetric CN stretching vibration of the acetonitrile molecules is absent (Figure S8).

elements.content: It is noted that XRPD investigations of the residue obtained after the second TG step indicate the formation of a very low crystallinity material. Its powder pattern is completely different from that of 1-MeCN, cannot be indexed, and thus the structure of this crystalline phase is unknown (Figure S9). Finally, temperature dependent XRPD investigations prove that no additional crystalline phase is obtained after the third TG step (Figure S10).

elements.content: To investigate if the acetonitrile guest molecules can be removed at room temperature in vacuum, a sample of 1-MeCN was evacuated overnight and the residue was investigated by XRPD. The powder pattern of this sample is identical to that of the ansolvate 1 obtained by thermogravimetric measurements (Figure S11). Further investigations using time-dependent XRPD reveal that 1-MeCN already lost the acetonitrile molecules on storage at room temperature within a period of about one month (Figure S13). To check the reversibility of this reaction, 1 was stored in a saturated acetonitrile atmosphere for some hours at room temperature. XRPD measurements of this residue prove that 1 has been transformed back into 1-MeCN (). Thermogravimetric measurements of this sample show that the mass loss exactly corresponds to that of the pristine material, which indicates that 1 has been completely retransformed into 1-MeCN (Figure S13), and that acetonitrile was embedded was proven my mass spectrometry.

elements.content: We also checked whether other solvents can be incorporated. If 1 is stored in an ethanol atmosphere the powder pattern of this residue is very similar to that of 1-MeCN, indicating that ethanol is located in the pores (Figure S14). In contrast, if the ansolvate is stored in a humid or a methanol atmosphere, the products exhibit completely different powder patterns, which proves that compounds with a completely different structure have formed. Indexing of their XRPD pattern was not successful.

elements.content: Because the powder patterns of the solvate 1-MeCN and the ansolvate 1 are very similar, one can assume that only minor structural changes occur and that the structure of the solvate and the ansolvate is strongly related. It is assumed that the framework is rigid and does not collapse during solvent removal, and therefore, the reaction might be topotactic. However, because this cannot be proven by XRPD investigations, single crystal measurements were performed. After removing some of the solvent at elevated temperatures in vacuum, full data sets were measured and the amount of acetonitrile was determined by the refinement of the site occupation factor (sof) of the acetonitrile molecules, which are located in general positions. This leads to reasonable values, because for 1-MeCN the sof was refined to 0.996(6), which proves full occupation within the estimated standard deviation. However, the determination of the sof was only possible to some extent, because with decreasing acetonitrile content the intensity of all reflections hkl with h + k = 2n+1 decreases, and at a content of 0.455(8) the structure is already C-centered. This is obvious from reciprocal space plots, which are presented in Figures S15–S18. It is noted that the adsymm option in Platon already suggests space group C2/c at higher acetonitrile contents, even if the reflections that violate the C-centering are present. A detailed explanation of which structures were refined in space group P21/c and which in C2/c is given at the end of the SI. In space group C2/c the acetonitrile molecules are disordered around a twofold rotation axis, which together with the low solvent content prevents precise determination of the sof. Therefore, the refinements were performed without acetonitrile and the data were corrected for disordered solvent using the SQUEEZE option in Platon. By this procedure the void volume and the number of electrons within the voids were calculated, with the latter used as a measure for the acetonitrile content. As expected, with decreasing amount of solvent the unit cell and the void volume decrease ( and Figure S19).

Investigations on the Solvent Removal Using Single Crystals

Because the powder patterns of the solvate 1-MeCN and the ansolvate 1 are very similar, one can assume that only minor structural changes occur and that the structure of the solvate and the ansolvate is strongly related. It is assumed that the framework is rigid and does not collapse during solvent removal, and therefore, the reaction might be topotactic. However, because this cannot be proven by XRPD investigations, single crystal measurements were performed. After removing some of the solvent at elevated temperatures in vacuum, full data sets were measured and the amount of acetonitrile was determined by the refinement of the site occupation factor (sof) of the acetonitrile molecules, which are located in general positions. This leads to reasonable values, because for 1-MeCN the sof was refined to 0.996(6), which  proves full occupation within the estimated standard deviation. However, the determination of the sof was only possible to some extent, because with decreasing acetonitrile content the intensity of all reflections hkl with h + k = 2n+1 decreases, and at a content of 0.455(8) the structure is already C-centered. This is obvious from reciprocal space plots, which are presented in Figures S15-S18. It is noted that the adsymm option in Platon already suggests space group C2/c at higher acetonitrile contents, even if the reflections that violate the C-centering are present. A detailed explanation of which structures were refined in space group P21/c and which in C2/c is given at the end of the SI. In space group C2/c the acetonitrile molecules are disordered around a twofold rotation axis, which together with the low solvent content prevents precise determination of the sof. Therefore, the refinements were performed without acetonitrile and the data were corrected for disordered solvent using the SQUEEZE option in Platon. By this procedure the void volume and the number of electrons within the voids were calculated, with the latter used as a measure for the acetonitrile content. Please note that the refinement of the sof was only possible up to an acetonitrile content of 0.455(8), because at lower contents the symmetry changes from P to C and the solvent molecules are disordered around a twofold rotation axis.

elements.content: The fact that the unit cell volume decreases by only 23.8 Å3 (0.8%) shows that the framework is relatively rigid (Table S1). Afterward the channels are practically empty, indicating the formation of the ansolvate 1. The fact that some differences are observed if, e.g., the unit cell volume is measured as the function of the sof and of the number of electrons indicates that the latter is only a rough measure for the acetonitrile content (Figure S19). In this context one must keep in mind that the whole electron density is counted within the voids, which also will include contribution from other effects. Moreover, from the evolution of the unit cell and the void volume it is indicated that the change of symmetry might occur if about half of the acetonitrile molecules are removed. In this context, it is noted that all structures refined in P21/c can also be refined in space group C2/c, neglecting the weak superstructure reflections, which lead to comparable reliability factors. However, in this case the acetonitrile is disordered in two orientations because of symmetry and the hydrogen atoms cannot be located. In contrast, in space group P21/c the solvent molecules are perfectly ordered. Therefore, the decision for which composition the structure should be refined in P21/c or C2/c was made on the experimental observation if superstructure reflections can be observed or not, and this is obvious from the reciprocal space plots shown in Figures S15–S18.

elements.content: However, the lengths of the c-axis decreases with decreasing acetonitrile content, which might be expected if the solvent is stepwise removed ( and Figure S20). In contrast, the a-axis increases, whereas the b-axis decreases if the solvent is removed, which indicates some deformation of the layers and, as a consequence, a deformation of the pores ( and Figure S20). It is noted that only minor changes are detected in the Ni­(II) coordination on solvent removal (Table S4).

elements.content: Even if the XRPD and DTA-TG investigations have proven that the acetonitrile molecules can be reincorporated it is not proven that this reaction is also topotactic. Therefore, the acetonitrile was removed in selected crystals, which were stored in an acetonitrile atmosphere afterward. One of them was investigated by single crystal X-ray measurements, which proves that the super structure reflections appear again, which is accompanied by a change in the lattice type from C to P (Figure S18). This is comparable to a “klassengleicher” phase transition of index II from space group C2/c into P21/c, for which a group–subgroup relation exists. However, this is only some accidental observation, because the composition changes during this reaction excluding a phase transition of second order. It is noted, that after reincorporation of the solvent the sof was refined to 0.960(8), which shows nearly full occupation (Table S1). The components of the anisotropic displacement parameters are comparable to those obtained from the refinement of 1-MeCN, which indicates that the solvent molecules are well ordered. However, if microscopic images of the crystals of the pristine material 1-MeCN are compared with that after solvent removal and after reabsorption of acetonitrile, only minor changes are visible, but it is clear that such a reaction must proceed via nucleation and growth of a new phase leading to very small domains, which cannot be detected by optical microscopy or single crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure S21). Due to the strong 3D relationship between the solvate and the ansolvate, these domains are nearly perfectly oriented leading to a diffraction pattern comparable to that of a single crystal. This proves that this reaction is “topotactic” but the term single-crystal to single-crystal transformation is not justified. In this case one can assume that the acetonitrile molecules will enter and diffuse not only through the pores because they will also diffuse at the phase boundaries into the crystals, that cannot be detected by single crystal X-ray diffraction. If the solvent is removed and reloaded three times using a single crystal a very small and insignificant change of the mosaic spread is detected in the single crystal X-ray measurements.

elements.content: The potential microporosity of the ansolvate 1 was investigated by nitrogen sorption measurements at 77 K (). A reversible type I sorption behavior revealed a BET surface area of 376 m2 g–1 and a micropore volume of 0.166 cm3 g–1 (determined at p/p 0 = 0.5), indicating its microporous nature. Such materials might have potential applications in small molecule storage and separation. The slight increase at p/p 0 > 0.9 can be attributed to the condensation of nitrogen in micropores and interlayer voids.
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Measurements

The potential microporosity of the ansolvate 1 was investigated by nitrogen sorption measurements at 77 K (). A reversible type I sorption behavior revealed a BET surface area of 376 m2 g-1 and a micropore volume of 0.166 cm3 g-1 (determined at p/p 0 = 0.5), indicating its microporous nature. Such materials might have potential applications in small molecule storage and separation. The slight increase at p/p 0 > 0.9 can be attributed to the condensation of nitrogen in micropores and interlayer voids.

elements.content: Nitrogen adsorption isotherm for 1 at 77 K. The inset displays the low-pressure region showing two inflection points.
elements.clean_text: 5  Nitrogen adsorption isotherm for 1 at 77 K. The inset displays the low-pressure region showing two inflection points.

elements.content: The micropore volume is slightly smaller than the void volume 0.241 cm3 g–1 calculated with Platon for 1. However, it must be kept in mind that the pore volume was determined at much lower temperatures and one might not exclude that the pores in 1 were completely empty, even if practically no electron density was found in the pores. Moreover, the low-pressure region of the adsorption isotherm shows two distinct inflection points at p/p 0 = 0.0006 and 0.013, which point to the presence of two different micropore structures. However, from the structural investigations there is no hint for different pores, because in space group C2/c all channels are identical because of symmetry. Some irreversible structural rearrangement can be excluded because the XRPD patterns of the sample of 1 before and after the sorption measurement are identical (Figure S22).

elements.content: For both samples the magnetic susceptibility at room temperature is close to the value expected for separated S = 1 spins with g = 2.15(5), which corresponds well with typical values for Ni­(II) cations. At lower temperatures the χT product increases, which means that the exchange interaction mediated by the (NCS)2 bridges is ferromagnetic. This increase is monotonous and smooth down to 1.8 K, i.e., there is no sign of a magnetic transition (). The ratio of the susceptibilities for 1-MeCN and 1 gradually grows and reaches 2.5 at 1.8 K. This difference allowed us to test if the reversibility of removal and incorporation of MeCN observed by XRD can also be followed in the magnetic properties. For this purpose the susceptibility was measured for a sample (1ds) obtained by storing the dried sample 1 in a saturated MeCN atmosphere. The low field, low temperature susceptibility for 1ds is identical to that for 1-MeCN (see Figure S23). This figure also demonstrates that there is no difference between the susceptibility measured following zero-field cooling and field cooling.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Investigations

For both samples the magnetic susceptibility at room temperature is close to the value expected for separated S = 1 spins with g = 2.15(5), which corresponds well with typical values for Ni(II) cations. At lower temperatures the χT product increases, which means that the exchange interaction mediated by the (NCS)2 bridges is ferromagnetic. This increase is monotonous and smooth down to 1.8 K, i.e., there is no sign of a magnetic transition (). The ratio of the susceptibilities for 1-MeCN and 1 gradually grows and reaches 2.5 at 1.8 K. This difference allowed us to test if the reversibility of removal and incorporation of MeCN observed by XRD can also be followed in the magnetic properties. For this purpose the susceptibility was measured for a sample (1ds) obtained by storing the dried sample 1 in a saturated MeCN atmosphere. The low field, low temperature susceptibility for 1ds is identical to that for 1-MeCN (see Figure S23). This figure also demonstrates that there is no difference between the susceptibility measured following zero-field cooling and field cooling.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility of 1-MeCN (circles) and 1 (squares) measured at 100 Oe. Solid lines were fitted using the model of Heisenberg chain of S = 1 spins with exchange J with zero-field splitting parameter D (see text).
elements.clean_text: 6  Magnetic susceptibility of 1-MeCN (circles) and 1 (squares) measured at 100 Oe. Solid lines were fitted using the model of Heisenberg chain of S = 1 spins with exchange J with zero-field splitting parameter D (see text).

elements.content: Magnetization M measured at 1.8 K (Figure S24) exhibits differences for 1 and 1-MeCN only up to 5 kOe. At higher fields both curves overlap and reach 2.0 μB at 50 kOe, but M is still not saturated. No hysteresis loop is observed. The magnetization quickly increases, up to around 1 μB per Ni ion at 1 kOe for 1-MeCN, and the farther increase of M is much slower. Such M(H) curve is characteristic for an anisotropic (but simultaneously magnetically soft) ferromagnet or, as in this case, an anisotropic superparamagnet.

elements.content: In the crystal structure of 1-MeCN (NCS)2 bridges provide the path for exchange interaction between the Ni­(II) cations, producing a system of infinite chains. All (NCS)2 bridges are identical and the chains are well separated by the bulky 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine ligands, in all directions in the crystal structure. This limits the interchain exchange interactions to only dipolar interactions. For the Ni­(II) cation the zero-field splitting (zfs) is usually present due to first-order orbital momentum, and its influence on the magnetic properties of powder samples becomes visible only at low temperature. All Ni­(II) cations in 1-MeCN have identical coordination and orientation, as they are related by a 21 screw-axis. In the simplest case of axially distorted octahedral surrounding the Hamiltonian that determines magnetic properties reads Η̂ = Η̂ e x c h + Η̂ z f s + Η̂ Z e e m a n = − J ∑ i S⃗ i S⃗ i + 1 + D ∑ i ( S i z ) 2 + g μ B H⃗ ∑ i S⃗ i with J > 0. The early solutions for similar systems are based on extrapolation of results for small rings of few spins. This method was more recently complemented, e.g., by a Green-function approach approximation to calculate the specific heat or longitudinal susceptibility, as well as by quantum Monte Carlo simulations but without ready results applicable for our case. The antiferromagnetic case, J < 0, is studied more attentively in the literature, due to the appearance of the Haldane phase.
elements.clean_text:
Quantum Heisenberg Chain for S = 1 with zfs

In the crystal structure of 1-MeCN (NCS)2 bridges provide the path for exchange interaction between the Ni(II) cations, producing a system of infinite chains. All (NCS)2 bridges are identical and the chains are well separated by the bulky 4-(Boc-amino)pyridine ligands, in all directions in the crystal structure. This limits the interchain exchange interactions to only dipolar interactions. For the Ni(II) cation the zero-field splitting (zfs) is usually present due to first-order orbital momentum, and its influence on the magnetic properties of powder samples becomes visible only at low temperature. All Ni(II) cations in 1-MeCN have identical coordination and orientation, as they are related by a 21 screw-axis. In the simplest case of axially distorted octahedral surrounding the Hamiltonian that determines magnetic properties reads    Η̂ =   Η̂   e x c h   +   Η̂   z f s   +   Η̂   Z e e m a n   = - J   ∑   i      S⃗   i     S⃗   i + 1    + D   ∑   i      (   S   i   z   )   2    + g   μ   B   H⃗   ∑   i      S⃗   i      with J > 0. The early solutions for similar systems are based on extrapolation of results for small rings of few spins. This method was more recently complemented, e.g., by a Green-function approach approximation to calculate the specific heat or longitudinal susceptibility, as well as by quantum Monte Carlo simulations but without ready  results applicable for our case. The antiferromagnetic case, J < 0, is studied more attentively in the literature, due to the appearance of the Haldane phase.

elements.content: In order to calculate the magnetic properties of this system we employed techniques based on density matrix renormalization group (DMRG), which provide a state-of-the-art toolbox for simulation of quantum systems in one dimension; see refs for review. It is based on the representation of the quantum state in the form of a matrix product state (MPS) which is particularly useful to describe both low-energy states and thermal states of local Hamiltonians, for which usually very modest bond dimensioni.e., the size of matrices appearing in MPSis sufficient to capture the entanglement in those states and approximate them with effectively exponential accuracy. The maximal bond dimension is then used to control the quality of approximation and acts as a cutoff parameter in the algorithm. In order to simulate the state at finite temperature we employed the purification approach, where the density matrix (1/Z)exp­(−Ĥ/k B T) is expressed as a pure state in the enlarged Hilbert space spanned by the system plus its auxiliary copy. Density matrix at infinite temperature has a trivial MPS representation in this case and the state at finite temperature can be obtained by starting with state at infinite temperature and simulating the imaginary time evolution. To that end, we used the time dependent variational principle (TDVP) approach. As the system we are studying is translationally invariant we work directly in the thermodynamic limit, which is done by assuming that MPS representation of the infinite system is uniform, i.e., matrices corresponding to different lattice sites are the same.

In order to simulate the state at finite temperature we employed the purification approach, where the density matrix (1/Z)exp(-Ĥ/k B T) is expressed as a pure state in the enlarged Hilbert space spanned by the system plus its auxiliary copy. Density matrix at infinite temperature has a trivial MPS representation in this case and the state at finite temperature can be obtained by starting with state at infinite temperature and simulating the imaginary time evolution. To that end, we used the time dependent variational principle (TDVP) approach. As the system we are studying is translationally invariant we work directly in the thermodynamic limit, which is done by assuming that MPS representation of the infinite system is uniform, i.e., matrices corresponding to different lattice sites are the same.

elements.content: By having the representation of the density matrix in the form of MPS, it is easy to calculate expectation values of local observables. In order to find magnetic susceptibility for fixed nonzero H⃗ we calculate magnetization in the direction of the field. Similarly energy density ⟨E⟩ is found by calculating the expectation value of the on-site and nearest-neighbor operators appearing in the Hamiltonian, and the specific heat C = d⟨E⟩/dT is then found numerically from the energy difference at a small step dT. To ensure the convergence we checked both different bond dimensions and discrete time steps used in the simulation of the imaginary time evolution obtaining consistent results. The susceptibility for the powder sample was calculated as χ = (2χ x + χ z )/3 (see Figure S25 for the test of validity of this approximation). This was done for different values of parameters of D and J; the fixed field H = 100 Oe as used in the experiment, and factor g = 2.2, close to the values expected for Ni­(II) cations ( and S26). The specific heat curves for H = 0 are shown in Figure S27.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility χ (powder average, shown χT product) calculated with the DMRG method for the Heisenberg chain of spins S = 1 for fixed exchange interaction J and different zero-field splitting parameters D, g factor 2.2, and applied field H = 100 Oe. For comparison the data calculated with QMC and exact diagonalization are shown with points.

elements.content: The susceptibility obtained with DMRG was tested (see ) by comparison with susceptibility calculated by exact diagonalization for the finite ring of 8 Ni­(II) cations using the MAGPACK package. At high temperatures the results are identical; the difference appears at low temperature, where the finite size of the ring limits the maximal χT value and makes such exact calculations unusable for our case. The susceptibility for a much longer chain, comprising 1000 spins, was calculated using the quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) method based on the stochastic series expansion as implemented in the ALPS library. This implementation, however, does not allow to calculate the perpendicular susceptibility χ x , so the powder susceptibility could be obtained only for D = 0. In such case, identical results were obtained using QMC and DMRG approaches.

elements.content: An interesting result of these simulations is the fact that the presence of zfs can lead to an increase of χT, which is against expectations for isolated Ni­(II) cations, where, in both cases, D < 0 and D > 0, the value of χT averaged for powder sample decreases at low temperatures in comparison to D = 0. For the ferromagnetic chain of spins with D < 0 the divergence of the average χT at zero T is faster than in the case of D = 0. This is related to change of the divergence type from exponential in the former case (due to an energy gap in the spin states spectrum) to the power law in the latter case where the system exhibits a quantum critical point.

elements.content: In the current state of development, the DMRG method is suitable for calculation of a wide range of quantities for both finite and infinite, but one-dimensional spin systems. In principle it is possible to include more complicated site terms, e.g., including other distortions of zfs. However, the increased number of parameters to optimize the fit to the experimental data, together with the need to average over two angles and the required CPU time, makes such calculations more difficult.

elements.content: Curves simulated by DMRG were used to obtain curves for other values of J by scaling temperature, and to include other values of D by interpolation. χT is proportional to g 2. The parameters obtained from fitting the χT(T) curve to the experimental data for 1-MeCN are J = 6.1(1) K, D = −3.22(5) K, and g = 2.12(6), while for 1, J = 3.88(3) K, D = −3.32(3) K, and g = 2.12(5). The value of g is influenced by including the diamagnetic correction, but this does not affect obtained values of parameters J and D.

Analysis of the Magnetic Properties for 1-MeCN and 1 

Curves simulated by DMRG were used to obtain curves for other values of J by scaling temperature, and to include other values of D by interpolation. χT is proportional to g 2. The parameters obtained from fitting the χT(T) curve to the experimental data for 1-MeCN are J = 6.1(1) K, D = -3.22(5) K, and g = 2.12(6), while for 1, J = 3.88(3) K, D = -3.32(3) K, and g = 2.12(5). elements.content: The influence of J on χT spans up to temperature on the order of 10J. On the contrary, the influence of D is negligible for T > |D| (see ). On this basis, we obtained almost the same J values as above, by neglecting D and using only data above 8 K. Such an approach vastly simplifies the calculations, as it is enough to use QMC simulated data for a single value of J with simple temperature scaling.

elements.content: Heat capacity was measured for samples of 1-MeCN and 1. The parts of the same samples, treated in the same way (pressed into pellets, covered with Apiezon N grease, pumped at room temperature) were used simultaneously in repeated magnetic measurements for a test. The specific heat C is shown in as C/T as a function of T. The broad peak observed around 2 K is caused by both zfs and spin–spin correlation due to the exchange interaction. There is no additional sharp feature that would point to an onset of three-dimensional order due to dipolar interactions. Such a transition is inevitable, but the related entropy change may be very small for a quasi-one-dimensional system. Small inhomogeneities of the samples, e.g., caused by the fractional content of MeCN, can easily lead to blurring of such a transition and hiding it in C(T) data in the case of 1-MeCN and 1.

There is no additional sharp feature that would point to an onset of three-dimensional order due to dipolar interactions. Such a transition is inevitable, but the related entropy change may be very small for a quasi-one-dimensional system. elements.content: The specific heat experimental data were also used to fit J and D parameters, using curves calculated with the DMRG method (Figure S27), properly scaled and interpolated. Additionally, the phonon contribution was taken into account, using the low temperature limit of the Debye model C phonon = AT 3. The parameters obtained from the fit using the data in the range 0.5–10 K are J = 6.53(2) K, D = −3.89(2) K, A = 0.0112(2) Jmol−1K−4 for 1-MeCN and J = 5.77(9) K, D = −3.04(4) K, A = 0.0096(8) Jmol−1K−4 for 1. The factor before C magn(T) was fixed to 1.0 during the procedure. When this factor was allowed to vary, values between 0.98 to 1.03 were obtained, with small effect on D and J.

elements.content: For 1-MeCN these parameters are close to the results obtained from magnetic measurements. For 1 the J value obtained from specific heat data is 1.5 times higher than that obtained from the analysis of the magnetic measurements. It is also visible in that the fitted curve deviates from the data points for 1. The measurement repeated for a further sample produced identical experimental data. Fixing the J value at 3.88 K leads to a much different curve. The most probable cause of such disagreement is the assumption that zfs Hamiltonian has an axial symmetry, which neglects the distortion E/D parameter. This leads to an overly high C/T(T) peak which has to be dumped in the fitting procedure by excessive J. For this reason the parameters D and J obtained from specific heat are likely flawed due to the model being oversimplified. This problem does not affect the J parameter obtained from magnetic measurements, since it can be obtained using solely the temperature range where zfs has no effect.

elements.content: The sign of the exchange interaction between the two Ni­(II) ions through the (NCS)2 bridge obtained for 1-MeCN and 1 is in agreement with ferromagnetic interaction observed earlier for all compounds comprising the same end-to-end double NCS bridge. This includes dimeric compounds, like, e.g., [Ni2(terpy)2(NCS)2(μ-NCS)2]·2H2O (J = 6.9 K, using the convention used here) as well as linear chains like, e.g., in Ni­(NCS)2(HIm)2 (J = 11.5 K). The last reference contains a table with magnetostructural data for six of such compounds and the discussion of the origins of ferromagnetic interaction. The geometrical parameters of these compounds are similar to that in 1-MeCN and 1, and thus, it is not surprising that the obtain J values are also ferromagnetic. Finally, the ferromagnetic interaction was also predicted by CDFT calculations for the layered compound Ni­(NCS)2(ethylisonicotinate)2 and this was also confirmed by magnetic measurements.

This includes dimeric compounds, like, e.g., [Ni2(terpy)2(NCS)2(μ-NCS)2]⋅2H2O (J = 6.9 K, using the convention used here) as well as linear chains like, e.g., in Ni(NCS)2(HIm)2 (J = 11.5 K). The last reference contains a table with magnetostructural data for six of such compounds and the discussion of the origins of ferromagnetic interaction. The geometrical parameters of these compounds are similar to that in 1-MeCN and 1, and thus, it is not surprising that the obtain J values are also ferromagnetic. Finally, the ferromagnetic interaction was also predicted by CDFT calculations for the layered compound Ni(NCS)2(ethylisonicotinate)2 and this was also confirmed by magnetic measurements.

elements.content: In the present contribution a new coordination polymer based on Ni thiocyanate was presented, in which Ni­(NCS)2 chains are linked by intermolecular hydrogen bonding into a three-dimensional network that contain pores in which acetonitrile is embedded. X-ray powder diffraction and single crystal measurements clearly show that the solvent can reversibly be removed in a topotactic reaction leading to a microporous material. If about half of the acetonitrile molecules is removed, a change of the lattice type from primitive into C-centered is observed. Interestingly, on resolvation in a saturated acetonitrile atmosphere the super structure reflections appear again and the space group changes back to P21/c. However, even if the solvent molecules in the pores might predominantly be responsible for the breaking of symmetry, one can assume that very small changes in the whole network will also contribute to the reduction of the lattice symmetry. This reversible and topotactic solvent removal is somehow surprising because the three-dimensional network is predominantly stabilized by only intermolecular hydrogen bonding. However, the small structural changes that occur on deintercalation of acetonitrile also lead to significant changes in the magnetic exchange constants. Simultaneously, the magnetic properties of presented Ni­(II) compounds are governed by ferromagnetic interaction between S = 1 spins, but zero-field splitting at low temperatures additionally enhances susceptibility. No magnetic ordering was detected and the system remains superparamagnetic. Theoretical curves of susceptibility and specific heat were calculated using DMRG based algorithm. The same method can be utilized to model magnetic behavior of other linear systems, including heterometallic single chain magnets with anisotropy due to zfs of Mn­(III) or based on Mn­(III) and organic radicals.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In the present contribution a new coordination polymer based on Ni thiocyanate was presented, in which Ni(NCS)2 chains are linked by intermolecular hydrogen bonding into a three-dimensional network that contain pores in which acetonitrile is embedded. X-ray powder diffraction and single crystal measurements clearly show that the solvent can reversibly be removed in a topotactic reaction leading to a microporous material. If about half of the acetonitrile molecules is removed, a change of the lattice type from primitive into C-centered is observed. Interestingly, on resolvation in a saturated acetonitrile atmosphere the super structure reflections appear again and the space group changes back to P21/c. However, even if the solvent molecules in the pores might predominantly be responsible for the breaking of symmetry, one can assume that very small changes in the whole network will also contribute to the reduction of the lattice symmetry. This reversible and topotactic solvent removal is somehow surprising because the three-dimensional network is predominantly stabilized by only intermolecular hydrogen bonding. However, the small structural changes that occur on deintercalation of acetonitrile also lead to significant changes in the magnetic exchange constants. Simultaneously, the magnetic properties of presented Ni(II) compounds are governed by ferromagnetic interaction between S = 1 spins, but zero-field splitting at low temperatures additionally enhances susceptibility. No magnetic ordering was detected and the system remains superparamagnetic. Theoretical curves of susceptibility and specific heat were calculated using DMRG based algorithm. The same method can be utilized to model magnetic behavior of other linear systems, including heterometallic single chain magnets with anisotropy due to zfs of Mn(III) or based on Mn(III) and organic radicals.

cln_elements.content: Suitable single crystals for X-ray structure determination were obtained by the reaction of Ni­(NCS)2 (8.9 mg, 0.05 mmol) with 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine (9.7 mg, 0.05 mmol) in 1.5 mL of acetonitrile in a closed test tube at room temperature for several weeks. A crystalline powder on a larger scale was obtained by the reaction of Ni­(NCS)2 (52.5 mg, 0.30 mmol) with 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine (116.5 mg, 0.60 mmol) in 2.5 mL acetonitrile. The residue formed was filtered off, washed with acetonitrile, and dried in air. Yield: 87.7%. Elemental analysis for C24H31N7NiO4S2 (604.38 g/mol): C 47.70, H 5.17, N 16.22, S 9.71. Found: C 47.64, H 5.21, N 16.09, S 10.65. IR (ATR): νmax (cm–1) = 3313 (m), 3177 (w), 2990 (w), 2130 (m), 2111 (s), 1704 (s), 1610 (m), 1590 (s), 1517 (s), 1502 (m), 1422 (m), 1395 (m), 1369 (m), 1332 (m), 1277 (s), 1256 (s), 1238 (m), 1209 (s), 1150 (s), 1107 (m), 1058 (m), 1016 (s), 954 (w), 909 (w), 831 (s), 780 (m), 751 (m), 706 (m), 661 (m), 608 (m), 539 (s), 470 (m) (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).

cln_elements.content:
Measurements using simultaneously differential thermoanalysis and thermogravimetry (DTA-TG) on 1-MeCN at 1 °C/min until 500 °C shows four mass steps in the TG curve that are accompanied by endothermic events in the DTA curve (Figure S6). The experimental mass loss of the first step of 6.9% is in very good agreement with that calculated for the removal of the solvent molecules (Δm calc. = 6.8%). The second mass step of 32.7% points to the removal of half of the 4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine ligands (Δm calc. = 32.1%), that might lead to a compound of composition Ni­(NCS)2(4-(Boc-amino)­pyridine) (1). A closer look at the DTA and the DTG curve shows a double signal for the next step, which indicates that the last ligand is removed in discrete steps. If the ansolvate (1) obtained by thermogravimetric measurements after the first mass loss is investigated by XRPD only minor changes are observed but the intensity of the prominent (200) and (400) reflections decreased as already indicated by the XRPD pattern of 1-MeCN calculated with and without acetonitrile (Figure S7). The formation of 1 is also indicated by IR spectroscopic measurements, because the low intensity band at 2251 cm–1 that originates from the asymmetric CN stretching vibration of the acetonitrile molecules is absent (Figure S8).

Sorption Measurements

The potential microporosity of the ansolvate 1 was investigated by nitrogen sorption measurements at 77 K (). A reversible type I sorption behavior revealed a BET surface area of 376 m2 g–1 and a micropore volume of 0.166 cm3 g–1 (determined at p/p 0 = 0.5), indicating its microporous nature. Such materials might have potential applications in small molecule storage and separation. The slight increase at p/p 0 > 0.9 can be attributed to the condensation of nitrogen in micropores and interlayer voids.

Magnetization M measured at 1.8 K (Figure S24) exhibits differences for 1 and 1-MeCN only up to 5 kOe. At higher fields both curves overlap and reach 2.0 μB at 50 kOe, but M is still not saturated. No hysteresis loop is observed. The magnetization quickly increases, up to around 1 μB per Ni ion at 1 kOe for 1-MeCN, and the farther increase of M is much slower. Such M(H) curve is characteristic for an anisotropic (but simultaneously magnetically soft) ferromagnet or, as in this case, an anisotropic superparamagnet.

cln_elements.content: Top: Crystal structure of 1-MeCN with view of the layered thiocyanate network along the a-axis. The C–H H atoms and the acetonitrile molecules are omitted for clarity and intermolecular N–H···O hydrogen bonding is shown as dashed lines. Bottom: Arrangement of the acetonitrile guest molecules in the channels with C–H···N hydrogen bonding shown as dashed lines.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Top: Crystal structure of 1-MeCN with view of the layered thiocyanate network along the a-axis. The C-H H atoms and the acetonitrile molecules are omitted for clarity and intermolecular N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding is shown as dashed lines. Bottom: Arrangement of the acetonitrile guest molecules in the channels with C-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonding shown as dashed lines.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 1-MeCN with view along the c-axis. C–H H atoms are omitted for clarity and the N–H···O hydrogen bonding between the acetonitrile solvent molecules is shown as dashed lines and the acetonitrile molecules within the channels are shown additionally as van der Waals spheres.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of 1-MeCN with view along the c-axis. C-H H atoms are omitted for clarity and the N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding between the acetonitrile solvent molecules is shown as dashed lines and the acetonitrile molecules within the channels are shown additionally as van der Waals spheres.

cln_elements.content: XRPD patterns of 1-MeCN (A), 1 (B), and the residue obtained after storing 1 in a saturated acetonitrile atmosphere for 1 d at room temperature (C).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  XRPD patterns of 1-MeCN (A), 1 (B), and the residue obtained after storing 1 in a saturated acetonitrile atmosphere for 1 d at room temperature (C).

cln_elements.content: Unit cell volume as well as lengths of the a-, b-, and c-axes as a function of the number of electrons within the voids determined by SQUEEZE in Platon. Please note that the refinement of the sof was only possible up to an acetonitrile content of 0.455(8), because at lower contents the symmetry changes from P to C and the solvent molecules are disordered around a twofold rotation axis.

cln_elements.content: Nitrogen adsorption isotherm for 1 at 77 K. The inset displays the low-pressure region showing two inflection points.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Nitrogen adsorption isotherm for 1 at 77 K. The inset displays the low-pressure region showing two inflection points.

cln_elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility of 1-MeCN (circles) and 1 (squares) measured at 100 Oe. Solid lines were fitted using the model of Heisenberg chain of S = 1 spins with exchange J with zero-field splitting parameter D (see text).
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Magnetic susceptibility of 1-MeCN (circles) and 1 (squares) measured at 100 Oe. Solid lines were fitted using the model of Heisenberg chain of S = 1 spins with exchange J with zero-field splitting parameter D (see text).

cln_elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility χ (powder average, shown χT product) calculated with the DMRG method for the Heisenberg chain of spins S = 1 for fixed exchange interaction J and different zero-field splitting parameters D, g factor 2.2, and applied field H = 100 Oe. For comparison the data calculated with QMC and exact diagonalization are shown with points.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Magnetic susceptibility χ (powder average, shown χT product) calculated with the DMRG method for the Heisenberg chain of spins S = 1 for fixed exchange interaction J and different zero-field splitting parameters D, g factor 2.2, and applied field H = 100 Oe. For comparison the data calculated with QMC and exact diagonalization are shown with points.

cln_elements.content: Temperature dependence of the low-temperature specific heat C measured for 1-MeCN (circles) and 1 (squares) at zero field. The lines were fitted using the model of chain of S = 1 spins with zero-field splitting and Heisenberg exchange (see text).
